When a TCAS conflict has been solved, what is the correct procedure to be followed? 
 The pilot shall report “clear of conflict” and then:

options.text: Return to the assigned routing and altitude in the most direct manner unless otherwise instructed by ATC.
Turn direct to the next waypoint of the FMS flight plan and select the closest altitude which does not cause a new TCAS conflict.
Continue on present heading and maintain altitude until further advised by ATC.
Enter a holding pattern and resume previous altitude until further advised by ATC.

Your TCAS

options.text: can generate coordinated resolution advisories.
can generate coordinated resolution advisories by activating the on-board radar system.
can generate coordinated resolution advisories by interrogating the radar ground station.
cannot generate coordinated resolution advisories.

variant.question: TCAS uses data from the radio altimeter, to...

options.text: gradually suppress RAs as the aircraft nears terrain.
gradually improve RAs as the aircraft nears terrain.
coordinate TAs between aircraft.
provide ground proximity warnings.

variant.question: When an intruder is equipped with a serviceable mode C transponder, the TCAS II can generate a:

options.text: traffic advisory and vertical resolution advisory.
vertical traffic advisory and an horizontal resolution advisory.
traffic advisory and horizontal resolution advisory.
traffic advisory, vertical and horizontal resolution advisory.

variant.question: Both you and the 'intruder' aircraft are equipped with TCAS II. What alert is possible?

options.text: Coordinated resolution advisory (RA).
Coordinated traffic advisory (TA).
Horizontal resolution advisory (RA).
Automatically inform ATC if a resolution advisory (RA) is generated.

variant.question: TCAS interprets intruders with no Mode C information as

options.text: TA only.
RA in the horizontal axis.
RA in the vertical axis.
RA in the horizontal and vertical axis.

variant.question: (Refer to the annex). On the ND, the TCAS generates the intruder aircraft symbol represented in the annex. The correct intruder vertical information is:

options.text: 300 ft below, descending.
300 ft below, vertical separation reduced to less than 300 feet.
3000 ft above, descending.
3000 ft below, descending.

variant.question: (refer to the annex). On the ND, the TCAS generates the intruder aircraft symbol represented in the annex. The correct intruder vertical information is:

options.text: 300 ft below, descending.
30 ft below, vertical separation reduced to less than 30 feet.
300 ft above, descending.
30 ft below, descending.

variant.question: Concerning the TCAS II, when receiving a resolution advisory (RA), crew members should:

options.text: immediately initiate the required manoeuvre.
try to establish visual contact with the intruder before taking any evasive action.
immediately engage autopilot which will be temporarily controlled by the TCAS.
disregard this RA if the own aircraft is equipped with a mode S transponder.

variant.question: Concerning the TCAS II, when receiving a resolution advisory (RA), crew members should:

options.text: immediatly initiate the required manoeuvre.
immediatly engage autopilot which will be temporarily controlled by the TCAS.
try to establish visual contact with the intruder before taking any evasive action.
disregard this RA if they have a mode S transponder.

variant.question: Your aircraft and an intruding traffic are both TCAS II equipped. Your TCAS can...

options.text: generate a coordinated RA.
contact ATC in case of an RA.
provide a horizontal RA.
generate a coordinated TA.

variant.question:
The TCAS II data display devices can be in the form of:
 
1.  A specific dedicated screen
2.  A screen combined with the weather radar
3.  A variometer represented on a liquid crystal screen which allows the display of Traffic Advisory (TA) and Resolution Advisory (RA)
4.  An EFIS (Electronic Flight Instrument System) screen
 
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

options.text: 3 and 4
1, 2 and 3
1 and 3

variant.question:
Concerning the TCAS II:
1) neither advisory nor traffic display is provided for aircraft that do not have an operating transponder.
2) TCAS II operation is independent of ground-based air traffic control.
3) TCAS II operates on the secondary radar principle.
The combination re-grouping all the correct statements is:

Refer to figure 022-23.
On the ND, the TCAS generates the TA intruder aircraft symbol represented in the picture. The correct intruder information concerning this TA is:

options.text: 300 ft above and descending with a vertical speed of 500 ft/min or more.
300 ft below, vertical separation reduced to less than 300 ft
3 000 ft below, descending
3 000 ft above, descending

variant.question: When the intruding aircraft is equipped with a serviceable mode C transponder, the TCAS II (Traffic Collision Avoidance System) generates a

options.text: traffic advisory and vertical resolution advisory.
Trafic advisory, horizontal guidance
"traffic advisory" and horizontal resolution advisory
traffic advisory, vertical and horizontal resolution advisory.

variant.question: In a TAWS or TCAS,traffic advisory traffic is represented as :

options.text: A yellow cirlce
An empty white diamond
A white diamon
a red box

variant.question: Refer to the image. The letters QTX and adjacent symbol indicate...

options.text: VOR / DME
an airport
a TACAN.
a VOR.

variant.question: The T/C is ___ and it will be reached at approximately ___.

options.text: FMC calculated top of climb; 6 NM from present position
TCAS traffic; 6 NM from present position
FMC waypoint; 22:59 ZULU
actual top of climb; 22:59 ZULU
